title: 109_s1198
content: The Act is titled the "International Solid Waste Importation and Management Act of 2005." It amends the Solid Waste Disposal Act to include regulations on foreign municipal solid waste. The curr_chunk defines terms related to the Agreement Concerning the Transboundary Movement of Hazardous Waste between the United States and Canada, including 'Agreement,' 'foreign municipal solid waste,' and 'municipal solid waste.' The curr_chunk defines material discarded for disposal generated by households, public lodgings, commercial, institutional, and industrial sources, which is essentially the same as municipal solid waste and not subject to regulation. The curr_chunk lists inclusions under the term 'municipal solid waste' such as appliances, clothing, consumer product packaging, cosmetics, debris from construction, disposable diapers, food containers, food waste, household hazardous waste, office supplies, and paper. The term 'municipal solid waste' includes office supplies, paper, and yard waste. Exclusions are hazardous waste, contaminated soil and debris from response actions under environmental laws. The curr_chunk discusses recyclable materials that have been separated from waste destined for disposal, including scrap rubber for use as a fuel source. The curr_chunk describes solid waste generated by industrial facilities and transported for treatment, storage, or disposal at compliant facilities. The curr_chunk describes specific criteria for waste facilities, including ownership, location, capacity dedication, and segregation of medical waste. The curr_chunk outlines criteria for waste facilities, including sewage sludge, combustion ash, and waste from manufacturing operations. It also addresses the management of foreign municipal solid waste until regulations are implemented. The curr_chunk discusses the authority of states to regulate the receipt and disposal of foreign municipal solid waste. It clarifies that existing state laws will not be affected by new regulations. The curr_chunk outlines that state actions under the section will not unduly burden interstate or foreign commerce and will not discriminate against it. It also clarifies that the section does not impact international trade obligations. The Administrator will perform the functions of the Designated Authority of the United States regarding importation and. The Administrator will implement and enforce regulations for the importation and exportation of municipal solid waste under the Agreement, giving weight to the views of states and local authorities. The importation of waste must consider local government views, impact on recycling programs, landfill capacity, air emissions, road deterioration, homeland security, and public health. The Agreement prohibits the import, transport, or export of municipal solid waste for final disposal or incineration in violation of the agreement. The Administrator can issue compliance orders or commence civil actions for violations of the section. The district court can issue injunctions for violations, with a maximum penalty of $25,000 per day of noncompliance. The Administrator considers seriousness and good faith efforts in penalty assessment. Orders become final within 30 days unless contested. The Administrator can conduct a public hearing if requested within 30 days of an order being served. They have the authority to issue subpoenas and establish discovery rules. Failure to comply with a compliance order may result in the assessment of a civil penalty. The Administrator can assess a civil penalty of up to $25,000 per day for noncompliance with an order. A conforming amendment is made to the Solid Waste Disposal Act. "Sec. 4011. Foreign municipal solid waste" is a provision related to waste disposal regulations.
